reviews.text: I can only take so much messiah talk in science fiction, especially when it’s coming from Javier Bardem and Timothée Chalamet, both of whom I generally like, but here all I could think about was that they’d played Desi Arnaz and Bob Dylan.
reviews.author: A.S. Hamrah

reviews.text: The massive cast, who could have easily felt like a Shakespeare-on-the-Beach ensemble, have fully bought in and are working overtime to ensure we do too.
reviews.author: Conor Bryce

reviews.text: I found reasons to avoid it all year long. Finally catching it on the small screen, I was enthralled, mostly thanks to Zendaya distracting from the tiresome Atreides white messiah complex, but also because it finally embraced BIG sci-fi battles
reviews.author: Stephen A. Russell

reviews.text: I'm constantly in awe of Villeneuve, and this chapter was the movie we were all waiting for.
reviews.author: Tom Santilli

reviews.text: A very good film, but one that falls short of that elusive classic status.
reviews.author: Grant Watson

reviews.text: Right from sound, camera work, and VFX to sharp and crisp editing, Dune 2 aces in every technical department.
reviews.author: Ganesh Aaglave

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve's sequel is a beautiful crash bang wallop of a film that is overpowering in its splendour and scale - a sci-fi film for people who don’t like sci-fi.
reviews.author: Francesca Steele

reviews.text: Bigger, bolder and more satisfying, Dune: Part Two triumphs over its predecessor.
reviews.author: Kip Mooney

reviews.text: Pt. 2 is massive, mind-blowing, less complex with much better pacing, better character development and expands the DuneMovie verse with culminating powers.
reviews.author: Nadya Martinez

reviews.text: It almost feels like a miracle that Denis Villeneuve got to make a Dune adaptation this bold and daring in the current studio system.
reviews.author: Andrew J. Salazar

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a masterpiece that surpasses the high expectations set by Part One, a movie so good, it will make you forget the horror of its popcorn bucket.
reviews.author: Matthew Huff

reviews.text: A monstrous achievement for the Sci-Fi genre, Denis Villeneuve’s Dune Part Two is all guts and glory with an end result that feels like sanctified storytelling.
reviews.author: Brittany Patrice Witherspoon

reviews.text: I need a buddy comedy between Stilgar and Josh Brolin's Gurney Halleck.
reviews.author: Pete Vonder Haar

reviews.text: Just as The Empire Strikes Back was an improvement upon A New Hope, this too is an improvement upon its predecessor. It’s a perfect sci-fi epic.
reviews.author: Joshua Ryan

reviews.text: For all its talk about centuries-old religious sects, intergalactic trading guilds, and foretold messiahs, Dune: Part Two is a movie about power and the material resources used to secure it.
reviews.author: Joe George

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve’s much-awaited sequel to 2021’s spi-fi epic, Dune, is the first truly great film of 2024. Dune: Part Two’s scope is awe-inspiring, its pacing is electric, and the themes it explores are suspenseful and thought-provoking.
reviews.author: Calum Cooper

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two leads you on with the idea that we’re watching an avenging hero. In reality, we’re seeing the inevitable, deeply disconcerting outcome of where following a messiah figure takes a culture.
reviews.author: Ben Wasserman

reviews.text: I would be remiss to not mention Rebecca Ferguson owning the screen as Lady Jessica. This film and cast is too stacked to give it fully adequate treatment in a mere blurb...
reviews.author: Kimberly Ricci

reviews.text: “Two: A Spice Odyssey”: Villeneuve’s gorgeous, brute parable of generational rage, interplanetary revenge and exploitation of masses for the production of magical fuel that extends dynastic rule... is freed from the garrulous exposition of the first.
reviews.author: Ray Pride

reviews.text: (Timothée Chalamet) is blessed with a remarkable head of hair that defies the desert’s dryness. There’s not an ounce of frizz on those wavy tresses.
reviews.author: Dana Barbuto

reviews.text: Villeneuve continues to push boundaries by creating thematically rich epics. We take these movies for granted, but when filmmakers are asked to take fewer risks, I am grateful for weird, grim blockbusters like Dune: Part Two.
reviews.author: Edgar Ortega

reviews.text: Villeneuve sets a new standard for big-budget, premium-format-ready filmmaking, delivering an aesthetic masterwork that shames its peers.
reviews.author: Brandon Lewis

reviews.text: When viewed as one long film with an intermission, Dune is a spectacular achievement. The problem is the intermission took three years.
reviews.author: Joonatan Itkonen

reviews.text: The weight of this world is presented as a matter-of-fact reality, and this solemn approach adds weight to the drama even when individual elements do not coalesce. We take the events here with operatic seriousness, all the way to their bitter end.
reviews.author: Andrew Kendall

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve's long-awaited sequel, Dune: Part Two, effectively delivers the full force of Frank Herbert's epic saga and is set to be a modern classic.
reviews.author: Farah Daley

reviews.text: Dune Part 2 is bolder and much more bombastic than the first instalment. In terms of cinematography and direction, this film is comparable to the sweeping epics of David Lean’s Lawrence of Arabia, Star Wars and Blade Runner.
reviews.author: Rosalynn Try-Hane

reviews.text: Dune is a story that combines science fiction, religion, ecology, amazing production value, and a dozen well-known actors. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Pablo O. Scholz

reviews.text: The key issues of Dune remain the key issues of Dune, but Denis Villeneuve has created a visual language for Dune that finally gives this epic its cinematic due.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: A triumph of style over substance.
reviews.author: Milana Vujkov

reviews.text: That lull of a bridge episode pushing us forward with action scenes and betrayal so that the lines can be drawn in the sand for future drama (this is pretty much an over-long epilogue leading towards MESSIAH).
reviews.author: Jared Mobarak

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve finds the humanity at the core of this sprawling sci-fi epic.
reviews.author: Chris McCoy

reviews.text: If Part One was more interesting in terms of plotting and character development, Part Two scores slightly higher in political intrigue and sheer spectacle, even if the dictates of the storyline sometimes make it feel more familiar (Lawrence of Arrakis?).
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: If Villeneuve makes good on his recent talk of making a third movie (based on Herbert’s sequel, “Dune Messiah”), “Dune: Part Two” is the downpayment that tells us it’s going to be spectacular.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a generational film; the rare release that reaffirms why I believe in cinema.
reviews.author: Griffin Schiller

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two features the same technical brilliance as the first film, as well as a remarkably talented cast, but it also suffers from the same problems as before thanks to a weak screenplay with poor story & character development and sluggish pacing.
reviews.author: Jeff Beck

reviews.text: It’s a credit to Villeneuve and his team that these films are as impossibly good as they can be, even when aspects are unevenly approached in order to play with so many characters in the story.
reviews.author: Douglas Davidson

reviews.text: There's some incredible world building and cinematography here but I didn't feel emotionally connected to any of the characters.
reviews.author: Justin Brown

reviews.text: It is a visual marvel that is unevenly paced and emotionally distant. Solid sci-fi film but was left with an empty feeling that didn't excite me for what may come next.
reviews.author: Brandon Collins

reviews.text: So alien in appearance, so human in its themes, Dune: Part Two is a peerless sci-fi film for the ages.
reviews.author: James Mottram

reviews.text: I drank a Red Bull before seeing Dune: Part 2. ... I should have had two. Maybe then it would have been easier to get through this at times ponderous and repetitive sci-fi sequel.
reviews.author: Tim Miller

reviews.text: ...a ponderous and terminally underwhelming (and uninvolving) endeavor that strikes all the wrong notes right from the get-go...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: Villeneuve delivers a certain solemnity through the visual and sounding side, but the land swallows his narrative and spits out the residues in the sand. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Yasser Medina

reviews.text: Villeneuve gives us much more to appreciate in his second Dune missive: Rousing action sequences ranging from worm-riding to tense knife fights and large-scale battles, and a thorough seat-soaker of a finale which combines all of the above.
reviews.author: John Serba

reviews.text: From self-parody to epic, "Dune, part two", by Denis Villeneuve, contains several possible versions of itself, but none truly great. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ernesto Diezmartinez

reviews.text: We get so many movies that use up the space Dune: Part Two does, but a very, very few manage to do so much with a canvas like this. Much like the great sequels before it, this film is essential.
reviews.author: Cory Woodroof

reviews.text: Villeneuve brings the epic scope, Zendaya brings the heart and humanity.
reviews.author: Rob Hunter

reviews.text: When all is said and done, this can only be described as an unapologetic rave.... Director Denis Villeneuve jumps into what could easily be a by-the-books franchise sequel and creates a cinematic feast for the senses.
reviews.author: Kimberly Pierce

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a must-watch epic sci-fi, visually stunning, adventure that could already be considered the best movie of the year.
reviews.author: Emmanuel Noisette

reviews.text: As a sequel, it works for the same reasons that make The Empire Strikes Back so many people’s favourite Star Wars film: there’s a darkness, a bleakness, that makes the fist-pumping moments feel all-the-more earned.
reviews.author: Philip De Semlyen

reviews.text: ...rich in multilayered world-building. While its dense story might leave some cold, this is a movie meant for big-screen grandeur, from the detailed costumes to the cinematography, special effects, and score.
reviews.author: Valerie Kalfrin

reviews.text: For much of its 167-minute runtime, the action builds itself up slowly but surely, teasingly incremental in its climb – but in its final act, Paul’s story hurtles its way towards a thunderous, earth-shattering climax.
reviews.author: Joe Muldoon

reviews.text: A must watch! [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jorge Rivera Rubio

reviews.text: The film is exquisitely beautiful and immersive, breathtaking in scope, and fearless in delivering stunning action sequences that are so vivid they practically erupt from the screen.
reviews.author: Lee Zumpe

reviews.text: Dune Part Two is bigger in almost every way. The visual effects, sound design, and production as a whole is immaculate. Narratively, it does feel a bit too unresolved by the end for my taste but hopefully Dune: Messiah comes sooner rather than later.
reviews.author: Cody Leach

reviews.text: Visually stunning yet sterile - with an emphasis on action, as opposed to exposition and character-development, resulting in a shallow, self-important sequel.
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: If you are watching “Dune: Part Two” with the right mindset, i.e. from Chani’s point of view, you should be watching the film with growing dread and concerned about Paul, not cheering how everything is coming together.
reviews.author: Sarah Vincent

reviews.text: As different from the first film as [Ridley Scott's] Alien is to [James Cameron's] Aliens. Same stuff, totally different genre!
reviews.author: Tim Cogshell

reviews.text: "Dune is a stunning, sweeping epic with a cast in command of their roles [...] Part Two really cements Dune as one of our greatest modern examples of epic genre worldbuilding."
reviews.author: Jeff Ewing

reviews.text: Holding her own amidst a powerful team, Zendaya exudes her own defiant looks in a harsh world where both people and nature challenge survival.
reviews.author: Robin Holabird

reviews.text: With an engaging story, a cast at their very best, along with stunning visuals, this is a masterpiece---as with the Oscar-winning first installment, Villeneuve shows visual mastery of, impressive cinematography, while maintaining an emotional heartbeat.
reviews.author: Sarah Knight Adamson

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two improves upon its predecessor, thanks to a bigger focus on the Fremen, but its inclusiveness is still watered down.
reviews.author: Gavin Spoors

reviews.text: “Dune: Part Two” is the type of film that will engross you with its beauty and complexity yet might confuse you at the same time. It is an epic tale worthy of the big-screen experience.
reviews.author: Reginald Ponder

reviews.text: "DUNE: PART TWO improves on its predecessor in some crucial ways, but the reliance on spectacle leaves gaps in the storytelling and a frustratingly ephemeral interest in the most interesting ideas the film brings forward."
reviews.author: Jim Ross

reviews.text: Directed with ferocity by Denis Villeneuve, the film pushes the envelope with its gripping dark atmosphere, suspenseful hunts and ambushes, intricate rituals and prophecies, psychedelic imagery, and exhilarating fights set against magnificent backdrops.
reviews.author: Filipe Freitas

reviews.text: There is little character development and it’s not for the literal-minded -- or anyone who has, despite their best efforts, paid some attention.
reviews.author: Deborah Ross

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve is the director of this massive undertaking... Also, on board here is composer Hans Zimmer with his unforgettable background music and Greig Fraser as the cinematographer who gets those gigantic sand worms into action.
reviews.author: Marie Asner

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a movie that feels like the culmination of everything that can make a big epic story like this great on the big screen.
reviews.author: William Evans

reviews.text: Tonally inconsistent, this second chapter rarely feels like a Villeneuve film.
reviews.author: Edwin Arnaudin

reviews.text: Collides dense sci-fi imagemaking with Herbert’s heady and prescient themes: the gravity of manufactured destiny, the untamable tendrils of belief, and a harrowing subversion of the hero’s journey.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Zhang

reviews.text: I found the film to be long and dragged out, while the cultural and religious aspects felt whitewashed. The film is star-studded with actors like Christopher Walken that felt more like glorified cameos that don’t add much to the story.
reviews.author: Kristen Maldonado

reviews.text: On every level, it's a set of cinematic genius. The craft is expertly made, and it shows in every shot, every note of the [score], and every scene that transports the audience to Arrakis.
reviews.author: Courtney Lanning

reviews.text: This was the best adaptation of a book that I've ever seen.
reviews.author: tt stern-enzi

reviews.text: The film warns us against the very thing it gives us. We watch from reclining chairs as Paul starts a holy war—our hands are clean. We get the heroic battles and the guilt on the side. Our hero is tortured so we don’t have to be.
reviews.author: Jorge Cotte

reviews.text: An incredible sci-fi epic that well surpasses the first part and achieves on every level. This might be the best sci-fi film we've had in many years and will likely be one of the best films of the year.
reviews.author: Paul Salfen

reviews.text: Dune feels without tears. Dune speaks without words.
reviews.author: Joshua Tyler

reviews.text: Toppled by arid self-importance.
reviews.author: Rubén Rosario

reviews.text: Epic visually, but the story is still hard to follow if you have not read the book.
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a singular vision painted on an enormous cinematic canvas. See it on the biggest screen you can.
reviews.author: Tim Brennan

reviews.text: With his second foray into Frank Herbert's universe, Denis Villeneuve has once again crafted a cinematic juggernaut designed to be seen on the biggest screen and heard through the most powerful sound system possible.
reviews.author: Víctor López G.

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve uses Dune: Part Two (2024), cowritten with Jon Spaihts, to examine the experience of being set before the prophecy, knowing you’re its intended subject. [... T]his narrative structure is famously hinted at in the Gospels.
reviews.author: CJ Sheu

reviews.text: The genius of the author, Herbert, and now the director, Villeneuve, is to weave all this complexity into an easily understood, and compelling story. It's been tried before, but this is the first time it has really worked.
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: Ugly, outrageous, brutal, and cynical; a genuinely terrifying film about power and politics as religion and control. There is little escapism here; hits square in the social plexus of horrifying 2024.
reviews.author: MaryAnn Johanson

reviews.text: Like George Lucas and Ridley Scott, filmmaker Denis Villeneuve proves himself a visionary by delivering one of the greatest science fiction films of all time.
reviews.author: Joe Friar

reviews.text: Where it really comes into its own as a hugely satisfying Hollywood sci-fi epic is in the action-adventure material, which is also backloaded, so the very long film seems to keep getting bigger and richer as it goes along.
reviews.author: Tim Brayton

reviews.text: [Dune 2] owes its intellectual interest to Herbert’s books. Is faith merely another resource to be exploited in the quest for power? ... Or is it real, tapping into a true well of knowledge and sustenance? The Dune series asks but doesn’t try to answer.
reviews.author: Rebecca Cusey

reviews.text: Grains of sand, not pixels, give Denis Villeneuve's spectacle its potent spice, in this urgent and compelling conclusion.
reviews.author: Chris Klimek

reviews.text: Like its predecessor, Dune Part Two is gorgeously filmed and prodigiously imagined.
reviews.author: Walter Chaw

reviews.text: The film's real center of gravity is its spectacle, the craft with which Villeneuve and his crew depict Herbert's stupendously complex worlds.
reviews.author: Margot Harrison

reviews.text: It's impressive filmmaking.
reviews.author: Tony Baker

reviews.text: An epic and spectacular sci-fi allegory with mass appeal.
reviews.author: Dwight Brown

reviews.text: Whether you think you're interested in a sci-fi or not, this is a powerful and quite beautiful reminder of what a stunning medium cinema can still be, when enough ambition, intelligence, artistry – and money – all come together in the same place. Bravo.
reviews.author: Graeme Tuckett

reviews.text: You know Villeneuve will get the spectacle right. The question is about the human drama… It almost all connected in Part Two.
reviews.author: Adam Kempenaar

reviews.text: I did not watch Dune: Part Two, I experienced it. From the beautiful majesty of its visuals to the awe-inspiring sound design and the fantastic production design, this film was an absolute joy to behold.
reviews.author: Matt Hudson

reviews.text: The rest of us get to be Zendaya’s Chani — charmed but not won over, and both expecting as well as deserving more than what she gets...
reviews.author: Deepanjana Pal

reviews.text: As with the Oscar-winning first instalment, Villeneuve shows mastery of scale and scope, with stunning cinematography and a thumping score from Hans Zimmer.
reviews.author: Jeremy Aspinall

reviews.text: This is easily Zendaya's best on-screen performance to date, and her future in the series will no doubt expand into further joy.
reviews.author: Callum Crumlish

reviews.text: The picture doesn´t ignore the Orientalism described by Edward Said in its own approach and how this influences the viewer's perception of the characters no matter how much the film tries to avoid those pitfalls. [Full review in Portuguese]
reviews.author: Pablo Villaça

reviews.text: Epic sci-fi film.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is the real deal in terms of sci-fi epics, and will probably end up being one of the most defining films of the genre for the next decade to come. It’s a tremendous work and stunning sequel that is simply unparalleled.
reviews.author: Rob Dean

reviews.text: It’s curious to say that a two-hour, 45-minute epic of this tonnage is holding something back, but Villeneuve is (once again) just as interested in prophesying the next film as he is in cementing the current one.
reviews.author: Chance Solem-Pfeifer

reviews.text: As in all of these sci-fi epics, there are plenty of scenes in which computer-generated characters drive computer-generated vehicles past computer-generated backdrops but, in "Dune," it feels human, slightly messy and organic.
reviews.author: Chris Hewitt

reviews.text: DUNE: PART TWO is an exceptional cinematic achievement in storytelling from Denis Villeneuve with a completely memorable score from Hans Zimmer and electric performances from Timothee Chalamet, Zendaya, Rebecca Ferguson and Austin Butler.
reviews.author: Lauren Veneziani

reviews.text: Cultural appropriation aside, there are too many characters to do them justice in a film more focused on the grandiose than the granular motivations of its side players or a more fervent exploration of imperialism and colonialism beyond "good vs bad."
reviews.author: Hanna Flint

reviews.text: It feels more confident [as] he’s benefiting from the fact that he’s done the hard work. He’s set up the lore and the backstory in the first movie. The exposition of like “Oh, look at how this spaceship works. [...] This is why Arrakis is important.”
reviews.author: Akhil Arora

reviews.text: What is really impressive about Part Two, is that despite how complex and like a miasma the plot becomes... the storytelling is so clear.
reviews.author: Mark Kermode

reviews.text: I still don’t love the material or the movies-but I recommend the sequel based on its kinetic first act, overall cast potency, thrilling sound, and overall satisfying qualities.
reviews.author: Dan Buffa

reviews.text: Impeccably shot, superb visual effects, and dripping with mostly strong performances from its entire cast, Villnueve’s latest will have you almost entirely invested in the dry, twisty, and monochromatic sci-fi drama for nearly all of its three hours.
reviews.author: Chris Sawin

reviews.text: Villeneuve conjures memories of “Lawrence of Arabia” more than once and gets some gorgeous visuals just holding on untouched sand dunes. When he introduces those worms, the action heats up and Chalamet gets to ride to glory.
reviews.author: Bruce R. Miller

reviews.text: Is Villeneuve's Dune a flawless adaptation? Not at all, nor is it a film free of blemishes. But it is one that solves its difficulties with finesse, and that stands out when it refuses to give in to the easy epic. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Yago García

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is undeniably spectacular. Whether and how much one is moved by that spectacle depends on large part on what else, if anything, the viewer wants from it.
reviews.author: Abbie Bernstein

reviews.text: With an unforgettable score, vivid visuals, and powerful performances, Dune: Part Two is what a sci-fi epic should be.
reviews.author: Britany Murphy

reviews.text: In Dune: Part Two, Villeneuve is less subtle with his choices, being aggressively vocal about the film’s intent, leaving very little room for ambiguity.
reviews.author: Tatsam Mukherjee

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two works as an epic conclusion to the introduction in the first Dune. Part Two works better as the conclusion, experiencing as one cohesive story rather than two parts of one whole.
reviews.author: Shah Shahid

reviews.text: The first "Dune" was fun; the follow-up no longer has the element of surprise and falls flat as a desert mouse getting steamrollered by a giant sand worm.
reviews.author: Mark Jackson

reviews.text: Finally, DUNE takes proper cinematic shape as the glorious sci-fi soap opera metaphor intended by Frank Herbert in Villeneuve's continuation, although its most potent offerings exist in the periphery.
reviews.author: Nicholas Bell

reviews.text: In terms of settling the various pending accounts of the first part, as well as introducing and resolving the second part, the film performs satisfactorily despite the occasional anticlimax... [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Benjamín Harguindey

reviews.text: I'll be telling my kids about the day I went to the theatre and watched the "Dune" saga. A celebration of human imagination, from its serious reflections to its wildest ideas. A cinematographic feat. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Victor Pineyro

reviews.text: It builds on what worked in the first film, and firmly establishes that it has been constructed out of not only an affection for the source material, but also a profound understanding of the tragedy at the heart of Herbert’s work.
reviews.author: Alexander Joenks

reviews.text: In a genre once jokingly called space opera, its grand aristocratic dynasties and passions justify the term.
reviews.author: Nick Hasted

reviews.text: This movie displays all manner of magnificence — black suns and 800mph winds, sandstorm assassins and massive stone ziggurats, all in a palette of grey and beige like a Mesopotamian temple renovated by Jasper Conran.
reviews.author: Tom Shone

reviews.text: The result is a staggering statement of near biblical approach — a risk-taking endeavor to storytelling that threatens to derail at any minute, but is kept whole by Villeneuve’s smartly conceived narrative.
reviews.author: Jordan Ruimy

reviews.text: Exceeds expectations in every way—except humanity.
reviews.author: Steven D. Greydanus

reviews.text: Dune 2 ignites the essence missing from its predecessor. With a pulsating heartbeat, it weaves characters and world-building into a sci-fi odyssey akin to a biblical epic.
reviews.author: John Flickinger

reviews.text: The recently released sequel "Dune: Part Two" is a large-scale visual and narrative contribution to the science fiction genre. Much more, it is a sophisticated twist on the Messiah cliché. All in a breathtakingly majestic setting. [Full Review in Spanish
reviews.author: Aglaia Berlutti

reviews.text: A major blockbuster that tells us a lot about colonisation, cultural appropriation, religious fervour, and the way we perceive our leaders. I liked “Dune: Part 2” even more than its predecessor. Full review in Spanish.
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: When the film centers on real locations and real structures and props Greig Fraser’s cinematography and Villeneuve’s vision come through clearly. Unfortunately, the film is heavily reliant on visual effects that often look poor at best.
reviews.author: Taylor Baker

reviews.text: There is so much to admire and praise here, Dune: Part Two is too big to ignore and a major cinematic event.
reviews.author: Michael Ward

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a breathtaking trip to another world, a fever dream from which we never want to wake.
reviews.author: Candice McMillan

reviews.text: The film is all exhilarating buildup leading to an unsatisfactory, and even somewhat perfunctory, payoff.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: This is what movie theaters exist for, this type of visual and complete story immersion.
reviews.author: Mark Hughes

reviews.text: Character, you may think, is not the point of a story like this one – it’s myth-making, allegory – but without real people to care about, there’s a ceiling on how invested we can become.
reviews.author: Ed Whitfield

reviews.text: This second part disregards most of the story’s nuances in favour of stunning action sequences that engulf the screen with battles and explosions, and feature the mightiness of the monstrous worms that inhabit the planet.
reviews.author: Sarah Gopaul

reviews.text: The second Dune instalment is jaw-on-the-floor spectacular. It elegantly weaves together top-tier special effects and arresting cinematography; it layers muscle, sinew and savagery on to the bones of Part One.
reviews.author: Wendy Ide

reviews.text: Overwhelming visuals and a pummeling score work hard to give this a constant bone-deep sense of profundity and meaning, even where the story itself is just a series of rebel attacks on farm trucks
reviews.author: Anthony Morris

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is why we go to the movies. Read up on the legend beforehand, especially if you haven’t seen Part One, settle in with some popcorn and marvel at what masterful filmmaking is all about.
reviews.author: T.J. Callahan

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two not only lives up to its anticipation but also sets a high bar for epic storytelling, leaving audiences craving more.
reviews.author: Kit Stone

reviews.text: Bouncing between something great and something terrible, Dune: Part Two lands firmly in the middle as a good yet ultimately flawed action epic.
reviews.author: Carson Timar

reviews.text: The special effects are spectacular; the costumes are arresting. Makeup and sets are out of this world. All the actors did a fine job, and I loved the dynamic between Chani and Paul.
reviews.author: Jeanine T. Abraham

reviews.text: Visually, this movie is incredibly stunning. I didn't like the original version, but this one is absolutely fantastic. It's easier to follow and the story is more straightforward. This is the rare case where the sequel is better than the original.
reviews.author: Michael Cook

reviews.text: If you like intergalactic shootings, you'll have it; But if you want more and get involved in metaphysics, apocalyptic ecology, religion, mass manipulation, fanaticism and love; You'll also find something to discuss for hours. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Laura Hiros

reviews.text: Lawrence of Arrakis meets Dr. Sandworm, or, How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bene Gesserit...The result is a blockbuster space opera that plays like a downbeat drama — we’re a long, long way from that famous galaxy far, far away.
reviews.author: Matthew Lickona

reviews.text:
I'm the biggest sucker on this planet for space opera shenanigans and proud giver-of-an-A-grade to Jupiter Ascending. With this budget and Villeneuve’s visuals, the worst this could be is a mostly good time. 

Dune 2: The Dunening is a mostly good time.
reviews.author: Ryan Syrek

reviews.text: The gifted Quebecois filmmaker unleashes all his big guns, including a couple of eyeworthy sandworm-riding experiences that might rock your soul while shaking the large-screen viewing venue at which you likely will be enjoying first-class cinema.
reviews.author: John Urbancich

reviews.text: The magnitude of the story and the level of artistry here is that rare occasion where you become so emersed in what you are watching you forget where you are when the credit roll.
reviews.author: Dustin Chase

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two was well worth the wait and exceeds all expectations.
reviews.author: Susan Kamyab

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two should be seen on the biggest screen you can find, but the story remains a riveting saga both classical and imaginative.
reviews.author: Alci Rengifo

reviews.text: Crucial to Villeneuve's take on Dune, and to his work in general, is seeing and feeling the minutiae; Paul's path and inner conflict, and Chani's reaction to it in particular, wouldn't cut as deeply otherwise.
reviews.author: Sarah Ward

reviews.text: With Dune: Part Two, the Canadian [Villeneuve] no longer has to prove anything. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ruben Peralta Rigaud

reviews.text: As a feat of project management, Dune: Part Two is undeniable. But given how fundamentally bizarre the world of Dune is—or should be—critical consensus seems like an odd goal. Shouldn't it be weirder?
reviews.author: Adam Nayman

reviews.text: For a big Hollywood blockbuster, Dune is unafraid to say some very dark things about religion, politics, power and violence.
reviews.author: Alison Gillmor

reviews.text: One of the year’s most anticipated films is nice to look at, but is let down by bland acting and a script that does no great service to its impressive cast.
reviews.author: Stephen Romei

reviews.text: A vast improvement on the first part with a complete story and epic scope.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: Even as we marvel at the stunning and immersive and Oscar-level cinematography, editing, score, visual effects, production design and sound in Denis Villeneuve’s Part Two, we’re reminded at every turn that this is an absolutely crazy story...
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: Dune 2 is more monumental than its predecessor, and if you’re a fan waiting for this big-screen behemoth, head to a theatre pronto.
reviews.author: Dhaval Roy

reviews.text: Chalamet too grows into his role as a reluctant rebel. The sequel makes room for humour. Stilgar's fervent appeals to Paul to embrace his inner messiah gives Javier Bardem some fine moments and a brooding, stately narrative a much-needed touch of levity.
reviews.author: Nandini Ramnath

reviews.text: Dune 2 is a visually stunning epic best consumed by those willing to invest in its world.
reviews.author: Joseph Robinson

reviews.text: The effects in this movie are gorgeous.
reviews.author: Mike Ryan

reviews.text: In an age of ever-increasing runtimes, it’s a rare achievement that the film’s 166-minute length feels earned.
reviews.author: Adam Mullins-Khatib

reviews.text: The ending of Dune Part Two is an improvement on the abrupt denouement of the first film, but it might still leave many in the audience a tad dissatisfied. On the positive side, it points to what Villeneuve has always had in mind - a trilogy.
reviews.author: Saibal Chatterjee

reviews.text: An impressive second half to Denis Villeneuve’s sci-fi epic progresses the dense plot instead of just laying the groundwork. It worms its way through imposing narrative obstacles with spicy directorial choices that may be commonly misinterpreted.
reviews.author: Eric Marchen

reviews.text: The second installment is significantly better. It seems pretty clear that Part One was the movie they had to make in order to do the one they really wanted to make.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: The world of Dune remains intriguingly complex, full of characters whose roles shift and evolve. Credit Villeneuve with filling the screen with enough exotic flavor and bold action to keep Dune vividly alive through two helpings.
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: This is truly one of most magnificent cinematic achievements of all time. Filled with breathtaking images, stunning action and a story that transcends the science fiction genre.
reviews.author: Rick Romancito

reviews.text: Villeneuve has raised the bar with Dune: Part Two, which now takes its place not just as the quintessential adaptation of the beloved novel -- but one of the top level series in its genre.
reviews.author: Micheal Compton

reviews.text: And as those prestige epics of yore were enlarged yea further by the imperial symphonics of Alex North and Miklos Rozsa, so here composer Hans Zimmer pushes for big, bigger, biggest.
reviews.author: Dennis Harvey

reviews.text: There are many moving parts in Dune: Part 2, but Villeneuve, who absorbed the novels of Frank Herbert as a teenager and has been ruminating on them ever since, proves more than equal to the task of bringing this story to the screen.
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: 'Dune' is a spectacular, procedural exercise, but 'Dune: Part Two' burns more calories.
reviews.author: Jeff Mitchell

reviews.text: If Dune: Part 1 didn't make you a believer; Part 2 just might.
reviews.author: Adam Olinger

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a powerfully effective spectacle and a masterful showcase of Villeneuve’s ability to realize worlds that are as beautiful as they are terrifying.
reviews.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore

reviews.text: Another speaker-rattling Hans Zimmer score powers ominous scenes on the planet Giedi Prime, where we meet the Baron's creepy, hairless heir Feyd-Rautha (a shaven Austin Butler). This second film is odder than the first.
reviews.author: Dulcie Pearce

reviews.text: The sheer craft on display along with the extraordinary storytelling results in an awe-inspiring and mature science-fiction blockbuster that immediately left me hoping for a Part Three.
reviews.author: Keith Garlington

reviews.text: "Dune: Part Two" is a masterpiece of epic science fiction filmmaking.
reviews.author: Damond Fudge

reviews.text: Dune is an epic adventure, but it’s also a morality tale with one of its main themes being the dangers of co-opting religion for political power.
reviews.author: Collin Garbarino

reviews.text: “Dune: Part Two” is stunning to look at, has memorable action scenes and a bevy of great performances. It loses a few points in setting up that the audience will have to pay to see at least one more film.
reviews.author: Rick Bentley

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is the counter balance to the recent blockbuster mediocrity. The story is dense. The characters are complex.  The world is captivating, and the production is flawless.  A must see film for sci-fi fans and cinephiles.
reviews.author: Sean Chandler

reviews.text: It was terrific, but exhausting, laboriously introducing us to the inter-planetary empire Herbert imagined, and the various dynasties grappling for power or simply survival.
reviews.author: Brian Viner

reviews.text: Instead of a theme park, it's more of a cathedral -- solemn, sober, beautiful and forbidding. Greig Fraser's photography and Hans Zimmer's score are full of majesty.
reviews.author: Kyle Smith

reviews.text: It’s all fatuous, like Peter Jackson’s Lord of the Rings films... Nothing in Villeneuve’s Dune series is as good as Zack Snyder’s Rebel Moon, which revives mythic understanding of both mankind’s history and fate.
reviews.author: Armond White

reviews.text: It’s an eye-popping, sonically stunning, highly original story with massively more action, character and plot than the 2021 Dune: Part One.
reviews.author: Tim Appelo

reviews.text: A wildly-entertaining, fully-realized spectacle that cements Villeneuve's place as a best-in-a-generation stylist but raises some questions about his understanding of story.
reviews.author: Vincent Mancini

reviews.text: While this sequel isn't without stuffy, slow spots, it's far more propulsive than its predecessor, and it manages to tell an exceedingly complex story in a gloriously visual and compelling way.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: Fails to remain engaging for more than a few scenes at a time, thanks to images that lack vitality. Instead of letting its most uncomfortable emotions linger, it takes a much more didactic approach.
reviews.author: Siddhant Adlakha

reviews.text: “Dune: Part Two” allows writer/director Denis Villeneuve to examine some weighty things like religion, politics and destiny in the middle of a sweeping, epic, visually stunning film. Plus, sandworms!
reviews.author: Mathew DeKinder

reviews.text: [Dune 2] reaches a fever pitch of seductive strangeness and operatic drama. It’s a tragedy about the dangers of power and fanatism, a romance, and a superb action movie. Villeneuve’s audacious vision has set a new standard for the cinematic sci-fi epic.
reviews.author: Alan Corr

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is an undeniable triumph -- a kinetic, beautifully shot exercise in wish-fulfillment whose denouement is so brutal it makes Taken seem like a model of nonviolent conflict resolution.
reviews.author: James Tarmy

reviews.text: The film's bounty of new characters and performers give it a heightened sense of drama that’s at once both grander and more nuanced than Part One’s.
reviews.author: Tom Gliatto

reviews.text: Villeneuve... seems somehow able to toggle between horizon-wide action spectacle and patient, up-close intimacy. His Dune project is an at-times breathtaking, thrilling departure for a genre rarely able to take us to genuinely new territory.
reviews.author: Hilary A White

reviews.text: The focus on the power and the limits of faith distinguishes the Dune films from the herd.
reviews.author: Kristian M. Lin

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve did what Peter Jackson did with Frank Herbert's work with Tolkien or Francis Ford Coppola with Puzo: a perfect adaptation that enriches the original text with its images.[Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Luis Bond

reviews.text: If this studious, spectacular shot at Herbert's saga can't always reconcile its warring impulses -- to dazzle and critique in equal measure -- then it's all part of the package, if not the point.
reviews.author: Luke Goodsell

reviews.text: I was a fan of first Dune in this series, although I logged similar complaints about its self-seriousness. This one is a little better; the action is just as thrilling but the characters are given more depth.
reviews.author: Max Weiss

reviews.text: Under the guidance of director Denis Villeneuve, it becomes a cinematic experience in that it’s a technical marvel showcasing the best of film with an immersive experience that almost literally knocks the viewers' socks off.
reviews.author: George M. Thomas

reviews.text: The revenge story comes to a satisfying conclusion here, while leaving the door open for more in the saga of Paul Atreides and his journey to becoming the chosen one.
reviews.author: John Lui

reviews.text: Here comes Dune: Part Two to restore your faith in big-budget, big-screen moviegoing.
reviews.author: Taylor Antrim

reviews.text: Visually splendid but a jumbled storytelling mess. Timothée Chalamet seems more like a sullen boy band expat than a galactic messiah. Zendaya is given little to do but glare resentfully for the last 90 minutes.
reviews.author: Christopher Lloyd

reviews.text: It all looks very nice, though deserts have a wearisome colour palate, and Mr Villeneuve fairly flogged the giant worms to death in the first one. It’s all a bit up itself, though Javier Bardem provides sly Life of Brian-style humour.
reviews.author: Paul Whitington

reviews.text: The imaginative visualization of its mise-en-scene makes Dune: Part Two a dazzling spectacle on a scale that is being lost in the streaming era and that requires to be seen on the big screen. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Hernán Ferreirós

reviews.text: Part Two is not merely an improvement but almost a different film. Villeneuve's imagination is unleashed here in a way that frequently thrills, even if the actual storytelling is sometimes dutiful; it's more Jodorowsky than Lucas.
reviews.author: Robert Horton

reviews.text: Composer Hans Zimmer added a fire engoine to the horn section.
reviews.author: James Verniere

reviews.text: Villeneuve spends so much time capturing the feel of Arrakis that he sometimes forgets that the audience needs to feel something toward Paul, perhaps the weakest character among the principal cast.
reviews.author: Ian Thomas Malone

reviews.text: Just sit back and be dazzled by the world that writer/director Denis Villeneuve has so artfully created. Wrapped in Hans Zimmer’s magical, masterful score, it’s a multi-sensory experience that surpasses the first installment.
reviews.author: Lisa Johnson Mandell

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is not only a masterful action film, but a cinematic look into the soul.
reviews.author: Carla Renata

reviews.text: Few theatrical experiences, this year or any, will be more dazzling.
reviews.author: Sean Collier

reviews.text: Part Two is even more mesmerizing than the first. Villeneuve's magnum opus is a visceral escapist entertainment that you could practically feel the desert heat on your skin & sand in your hair.
reviews.author: Ruth Maramis

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two at times expends an excess of severity and footage, particularly between the tests in the desert and the final battle. But it is also solid, attractive, and more exciting than the first installment. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Javier Ocaña

reviews.text: Production-wise, Dune: Part Two is a film that delivers stunning desert vistas alongside dreary empires of destruction, but its runtime and same-old perspectives feel like been there done that.
reviews.author: DarkSkyLady

reviews.text: Who knew it was possible to be so amazed and so bored at the same time?
reviews.author: A.A. Dowd

reviews.text: The performances match the breathtaking visuals, making Dune: Part Two a captivating and immersive cinematic experience.
reviews.author: Rebecca Murray

reviews.text: Despite veering from the content of the novel, and forgiving the lack of menace Austin Butler created, this was a phenomenal movie filled with glorious action, magnificent visuals and special effects, and passionate and dynamic performances.
reviews.author: Chris Joyce

reviews.text: Any pointed critique might get lost here in the spectacular sunsets, sleek knife fights, opulent wardrobes and blockbuster power. ... It grinds the rough edges off the source material in favour of symmetry and spectacle.
reviews.author: Kurt Halfyard

reviews.text: 'Dune: Part Two' gives star Timothée Chalamet richer material to play, but the film still doesn’t quite capture the heart.
reviews.author: André Hereford

reviews.text: This movie, more than the first part, is entirely on author Frank Herbert’s wavelength.
reviews.author: Jonathan W. Hickman

reviews.text: DUNE-heads unite, & props to dir Denis Villenueve & his team for properly delivering Frank Herbert's illuminating sci-fi story of courage and prophecy. Everything you want ... epic battle, romance and loyalty/betrayal is in this incredible film. Perfect!
reviews.author: Patrick McDonald

reviews.text: Ultimately, we end up with an abundance of craft and a forest of lore wrapped around personal narratives too flimsy to sustain marching feet.
reviews.author: Donald Clarke

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a towering achievement of artistic vision.... The only problem is, like Part One, the only way to accomplish this was to make something that is, for all intents and purposes, not even really a movie.
reviews.author: Jackson Weaver

reviews.text: The year’s first surefire blockbuster is a sequel that outdoes Denis Villeneuve’s first epic 2021 sand opera. OK, it’s a tad long and solemn,  but Chalamet and Zendaya are destiny-kissed lovers to die for, and the thundering spectacle is off the charts.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: If ... Dune took too much time getting to the point, the ... sequel is, perhaps, in too much of a rush to actually consider the many points it wants to make.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: 'Dune: Part Two' sets foot back on Arrakis with an ambitious fire in its eye, overcoming its unsteady but understandable hubris with cinematography and production value that comes utterly alive.
reviews.author: Charlotte Simmons

reviews.text: Throughout Villeneuve’s career, the director has had a marked disinterest in humanity. No matter the triumph or setback, each plot development and inflection point is as dry as the sands where film takes place.
reviews.author: Alan Zilberman

reviews.text: If he can pull off this planned trilogy, the “Dune” films will join “Metropolis” (1927), “2001: A Space Odyssey” (1968), and “Blade Runner” (1982) as among the most significant achievements in science fiction cinema and, indeed, in all film.
reviews.author: Daniel M. Kimmel

reviews.text: “Dune: Part Two” see’s filmmaker Denis Villeneuve stunningly best his 2021 entry at every spice-dusted turn.
reviews.author: Nate Adams

reviews.text: I wish this film had grabbed my head and heart more. But I recommend that you see it – preferably in Imax – and let the visuals and the entrancing score by Hans Zimmer wash over you.
reviews.author: Anupama Chopra

reviews.text: ... believable spectacle on a nigh impossible scale... Chalamet is more than just Willy Wonka (here), evolving from the son of an assassinated duke into a force of nature... it would have been nice to embrace more of the unique trappings of the novels.
reviews.author: Kevin A. Ranson

reviews.text: As much as Dune Two plays with religious archetypes and the universal appeal of “messiah” narratives, it adopts a decidedly skeptical posture toward the religious enterprise.
reviews.author: Brett McCracken

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two not only continues the brilliance of the first film but is a film that certainly sets a new bar for just how good sci-fi films should be. With stunning visuals, an engaging story and a cast at their very best this is a masterpiece.
reviews.author: David Griffiths

reviews.text: Throughout Dune: Part Two, I caught myself looking at the time, not because I was bored and wanted to see how much time was left, but quite the opposite; I was dreading the film ending.
reviews.author: Lauren Bradshaw

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two delivers mightily on the promises set in the first film with bountiful aplomb. It sets an incredibly high bar not only for blockbusters in 2024, but for sequels in this century.
reviews.author: Harris Dang

reviews.text: Splitting the films now makes sense in terms of telling this story properly and patiently, and this feels like the payoff for our patience.
reviews.author: Steven Prokopy

reviews.text: "D2" hits the ground howling and never lets up, lashed onward, once again, by the virtuoso camera strategies of Villeneuve and cinematographer Greig Fraser, and by Hans Zimmer's titanic score.
reviews.author: Kurt Loder

reviews.text: What began with an unfilmable novel is now one of the best double bills ever made.
reviews.author: Pat Mullen

reviews.text: To Villeneuve, size does matter.
reviews.author: Sean Burns

reviews.text: The dazzling visuals and intimate moments help to compensate for the movie’s sometimes plodding pace.
reviews.author: Russ Simmons

reviews.text: A triumph of craft and storytelling that serves as a potent mirror to the first part, as hubristic political gamesmanship is supplanted by the tragic weaponisation of religion. It also has Javier Bardem surfing a sandworm into battle, so yeah, I loved it.
reviews.author: Simon Miraudo

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two succeeds on its many storyline levels, big and small. Passion, power, corruption, oppression, romance, intimacy, and revenge all get their time in this sweeping spectacle.
reviews.author: Elias Savada

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two doesn’t just feel like a rewarding conclusion to all the attempted screen adaptations of Herbert’s novels, but also the fullest expression of ideas, themes and aesthetics Villeneuve has been working towards throughout his career.
reviews.author: Radheyan Simonpillai

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two feels like the right film for this moment. In a post-Barbenheimer world, where big blockbusters can also have something to say, this is the perfect sandstorm of filmmaking, performances, and vision.
reviews.author: Victoria Luxford

reviews.text: Neither a zippy adventure nor a metaphysical mind-bender, this Dune has the heaviness of an old-fashioned Hollywood epic.
reviews.author: Jake Wilson

reviews.text: This is the Imax experience the Avatar movies wish they could be: a spectacle with grand visuals and EQUALLY grand writing.
reviews.author: Doug Walker

reviews.text: Regardless of whether there is more to come, this latest chapter emerges as one of the most well-crafted works of cinema you'll see this year. With both spectacle and soul, it is a work that puts all other projects of this scale to absolute shame.
reviews.author: Chase Hutchinson

reviews.text: The casual audience will like the incredible imagery of Villeneuve and the A-List cast supporting it.
reviews.author: Alan Ng

reviews.text: "Dune: Part Two" tries to explore ideas about whether an outsider should lead and/or save a race of people, but the half-hearted efforts are almost as bad as if these notions hadn't been interrogated at all.
reviews.author: Odie Henderson

reviews.text: ... While the script allows itself the space to deepen the theme and characters of the first film, the director expands the scale of his audiovisual film. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Juanma Fernández París

reviews.text: The best addition is Austin Butler as the baron’s bald-pated, hypervicious nephew. It’s official: Butler no longer looks or sounds like Elvis Presley.
reviews.author: Peter Rainer

reviews.text: It belongs firmly to Zendaya, who gives the second half of Denis Villeneuve’s Frank Herbert adaptation an emotional tangibility that the first, in all its exotic majesty, eschewed.
reviews.author: Alison Willmore

reviews.text: “Dune Part 2” is state-of-the-art commercial cinema as it exists in 2024: It takes you someplace far away and brings it up close, with broad archetypes, nods to Big Ideas, and every bit of its vision dotted down to the last pixel.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: The serene beauty of the desert's quiet contrasts starkly with the intense conflict scenes in Dune: Part Two.
reviews.author: Allison Rose

reviews.text: Familiar? You bet. Exciting? Absolutely. "Dune" is huge. The whole movie thrums with bombastic images and sound.
reviews.author: Michael J. Casey

reviews.text: ...with a larger cast, wider focus and comprehensible, sublime action set-pieces, this vindicates Villeneuve’s gamble to hold back key characters from the first film...a unique brand of inscrutable alien cultures and other-worldly cinematic spice...
reviews.author: Eddie Harrison

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two brings the novel's themes to the forefront in a way that the first film could never quite manage, while also still delivering plenty of visceral action and awestruck world-building.
reviews.author: Andrew Wyatt

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is undoubtedly one of this year’s biggest cinematic experiences as Denis Villeneuve and co. dive deeper into the desert. Outstanding on pretty much all levels, the sequel is visually thrilling and narratively epic.
reviews.author: Nicola Austin

reviews.text: The spice expands consciousness–I wish Denis Villeneuve had at least experimented with it before he decided to navigate the spaceways of this science fiction epic.
reviews.author: Ryan Silberstein

reviews.text: Dune Part 2, is a big, wild vision, an answer to the stately elegance of the first film. It’s blockbuster filmmaking writ large, exciting and laced with high stakes.
reviews.author: Richard Crouse

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a true cinematic experience. It needs to be seen on the big screen.
reviews.author: Korey Coleman

reviews.text: This is a cinematic, monumental film that is sure to blow audiences away with its pure spectacle.
reviews.author: Jonathan Sim

reviews.text: 'Dune Part Two' is another stunning sci-fi achievement from director Denis Villenueve.
reviews.author: Thomas Stoneham-Judge

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve’s vision makes a powerful conclusion to Dune.
reviews.author: Karen Gordon

reviews.text: Saying that this film should be an hour longer sounds more loving that I intend, though my intentions are positive. As the conflict expands wider, the movie deserved to have the time and space that it allowed everything else in the film.
reviews.author: David Poland

reviews.text: Yet more than five hours into this saga, and with no real end in sight, all that super-sized spectacle ends up like footprints in a sandstorm: barely leaving an impression beyond the end credits.
reviews.author: Alistair Harkness

reviews.text: Big, bold, and equally grim as it is amorous, ‘Dune: Part Two’ inimitably balances its blockbuster psyche with an uncomfortable morality.
reviews.author: Peter Gray

reviews.text: Your worm is waiting, jump on and hang on tight.
reviews.author: Adam Graham

reviews.text: Villenueve's sense of scale is basically unmatched right now, and there are shots here that will take your breath away
reviews.author: Jason Adams

reviews.text: ... A science fiction masterpiece. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Andrea Zamora

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is bigger and bolder than the first installment, with sequences that range from beguiling and creative to brutal and commanding. Yet, he finds himself making some of the same mistakes that injured his 2021 feature.
reviews.author: Hector A. Gonzalez

reviews.text: Villeneuve aptly weaves the disparate threads of family, power, mysticism, religion, politics, and love in this second part of a strikingly visual film. Climb into the sandbox for this one.
reviews.author: Linda and Al Lerner

reviews.text: Villeneuve’s film is a grand success, working on an even broader canvas than the first Dune -- but it’s tinged with deep mournfulness, a quality that sets it apart from its blockbuster contemporaries.
reviews.author: David Sims

reviews.text: There is no shortage of sights and sounds to wow the senses in Dune: Part Two; the gigantic sandworms alone are worth the price of admission. But when the accompanying story becomes borderline incomprehensible, that visual feast winds up feeling hollow.
reviews.author: Alex Bentley

reviews.text: Now we know: Frank Herbert’s Dune can be filmed successfully... Villeneuve and his crew orchestrate this spectacle skilfully, without a trace of self-consciousness, let alone humour.
reviews.author: David Sexton

reviews.text: Villeneuve has taken the worst and most preachy bits from Avatar, about how imperialism is fuelled by the exploitation of natural resources, and seemingly repackaged them with an orange Instagram filter and a couple of dozen heavy brass “braaaaam”s...
reviews.author: Kevin Maher

reviews.text: It is precisely this discontinuous narration that makes "Dune: Part Two" a more uneven title than what lovers of fan-filled theaters could hope for. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ricardo Rosado

reviews.text: Movies executed on this sprawling, daunting scale don’t come along every day. Furthermore, movies this large rarely deliver such a massively ambitious, yet finely detailed vision as what we encounter in Dune: Part Two.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: “Dune: Part Two” builds a world that’s undeniably spectacular, compressing a sprawling, borderline incomprehensible story into an efficient narrative-delivery system.
reviews.author: Ann Hornaday

reviews.text: Villeneuve, who has given science-fiction cinema a much-needed shot in the arm and has made the kind of Dune adaptation that makes everybody see what your cooler nerdy friends saw when they read the books back in high school.
reviews.author: Nick Johnston

reviews.text: A visionary imagining of Herbert’s book on screen... Like its predecessor, this is less a popcorn “Star Wars”-like space adventure than a quasi-art film disguised as popular entertainment.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a stunning piece of cinema that brings the world of its source material to life, but can’t deliver a story that matches the brilliance of its world.
reviews.author: Kyle Logan

reviews.text: Starry sequel is mesmerizing from start to finish, but it's heavier than most sci-fi fare.
reviews.author: Christian Toto

reviews.text: Cinematic escape velocity, instantly achieved. Next stop, Arrakis.
reviews.author: Michael Burgin

reviews.text: Dune 2 is the much-anticipated pay-off, a vast improvement over the mythology-laden first film. Epic battles scenes, palace intrigue, romance and religious prophecies abound.
reviews.author: Scott Phillips

reviews.text: Epic in scope and astonishing in its world-building, Dune: Part Two combines jaw-dropping visuals with imaginative action and morally complex plotting to thrilling effect
reviews.author: Matthew Turner

reviews.text: Outstanding...actually makes you feel like you’ve watched something with real dramatic substance – along with awesome, ginormous sandworms.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: As a big-screen spectacle, Part Two exceeds Part One.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: Even those who, like me, came into the theater more or less Dune-indifferent may find themselves wanting another chapter...
reviews.author: Dana Stevens

reviews.text: Aside from being such an exquisite technical achievement, what makes “Dune Part Two” a masterpiece is that it’s always interrogating that same story, and why we need to keep telling it to ourselves in our art, in our politics, in our religion.
reviews.author: Rob Thomas

reviews.text: Those of us who retain a stubborn fondness for Lynch’s much maligned adaptation will sense what’s missing from Villeneuve’s: an imaginative density, a hint of psychoerotic danger, the grotesque, teeming aliveness of a fully inhabited world.
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: An engrossing sci-fi spectacle.
reviews.author: Casey Chong

reviews.text: Positively mind blowing --- director Denis Villeneuve and his magnificent cast and crew have created a nearly three-hour colossal achievement in filmmaking.
reviews.author: Jeanne Kaplan

reviews.text: For sci-fi buffs, it doesn’t get any better than the highly imaginative and immensely entertaining DUNE: PART TWO.
reviews.author: David Kaplan

reviews.text: …a true-blue(-eyed) triumph for modern mainstream cinema and an experience that can make even the biggest of projection screens feel even bigger.
reviews.author: Cain Noble-Davies

reviews.text: In his follow-up to the masterful first chapter, director Denis Villeneuve barrels through a complex story line to offer a visual feast, serving up one of the most jaw dropping cinematic events in years.
reviews.author: Joanna Langfield

reviews.text: Short of lassoing a sandworm, for the second film in a row, the screenwriting of Denis Villenueve and Jon Spaihts cannot achieve that next tier of swell and it painfully shows.
reviews.author: Don Shanahan

reviews.text: An absolute behemoth of filmmaking. A spectacular that truly serves the best cinema has to offer. It’s gigantic, epic, and sprawling... it engulfs your body and buries you in its immense scope and scale... This generation’s 'Return of the King.'
reviews.author: Dave Lee

reviews.text: Director Denis Villeneuve’s latest is breathless in scope, action, and artistry.
reviews.author: Jeff York

reviews.text: If the first part was full of intrigue, politics and betrayal, the follow-up is its ponderous playing out
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: One way or another, if there is a movie so far this year that deserves to be seen on the biggest screen possible, it is this one. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jorge Loser

reviews.text: Who says blockbusters can’t be high art?
reviews.author: Dan Scully

reviews.text: Villeneuve’s production is a grand and convincing argument that films – at least of this sort- are required viewing in a theater setting, though even the vast IMAX screens upon which it will be shown will strain to contain this epic vision.
reviews.author: Charles Koplinski

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a work of visceral beauty that proves that large-scale blockbusters can be exciting, mature, and deliver a captivating sci-fi epic. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: José Roberto Landaverde

reviews.text: “Dune: Part Two” is a sweeping and engaging continuation that will make you eager for a third installment.
reviews.author: Kristen Lopez

reviews.text: Truly, it’s the best reason to get up off the couch at home and go see it for yourself, at the best movie theater you can afford. I don’t know what else to say.
reviews.author: Peter Martin

reviews.text: A rushed and underdeveloped second chapter that feels strangely diminished compared to its predecessor.
reviews.author: Evan Dossey

reviews.text: A grand cinematic spectacle that takes its place as one of the greatest sci-fi films ever made
reviews.author: Doug Jamieson

reviews.text: Technically it’s phenomenal. But also what it’s delivering is truly epic and made me appreciate and become more immersed in this world than the first film.
reviews.author: Eric Goldman

reviews.text: A masterful melding of massive spectacle, heartfelt high-stakes performances, and astonishing visual artistry, “Dune: Part Two” expands the mythic hero’s journey to its full potential.
reviews.author: Lynn Venhaus

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is lightyears away from its predecessor, becoming a game changer for the science fiction genre. With powerful storytelling and a stronger cast, Dune: Part Two soars where most films dream of.
reviews.author: Joshua Mackey

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve delivers a massive, epic sci-fi spectacle with Dune Part Two, expanding the world and concepts first introduced in the books by Frank Herbert.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Harris

reviews.text: In all likelihood, Dune: Part Two will be revered in film history for years to come – it manages to be unlike anything we’ve seen before, yet comfortably familiar at the same time.
reviews.author: Josie Meléndez

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve successfully delivers on the setup established in Part 1, crafting an epic and gripping sci-fi tale that will captivate audiences.
reviews.author: Cris Parker

reviews.text: Not since the Lord of the Rings movies has there been something this committed to its singular vision, this brash, and this handsome.
reviews.author: Matt Lynch

reviews.text: Villeneuve’s construction of Dune’s bizarre universe is done with such conviction that we go along with the story’s portentousness, just as we accept the spectacle of characters hurtling atop giant sandworms like so many chariot-driving Ben-Hurs.
reviews.author: Jason Best

reviews.text: A sandy sci-fi spectacle with overtones of a scarily familiar world, a spectacular, sprawling extravaganza that shows the remarkable effects, star-studded casting and thrilling big-screen wallop a budget north of $120 million can get you.
reviews.author: Neil Pond

reviews.text: At its best when it uses the epic vistas of the desert to its advantage.
reviews.author: Sonny Bunch

reviews.text: Cooking with bolder savory spice – unlike anyone else has ever done with Herbert’s words – Denis Villeneuve's Dune Part Two is a masterpiece.
reviews.author: Rendy Jones

reviews.text: Beyond tapping into the source material’s vast potential for emotion and sociopolitical commentary, [Villeneuve] applies a formal bravado and seriousness found in history’s most substantial works of science fiction.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: A rousing, heartfelt and breathtaking spectacle.
reviews.author: Avi Offer

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve once again proves that he has desert power.
reviews.author: Marianna Neal

reviews.text: Director Denis Villeneuve comes up with a cracker of a starry action-laden sequel.
reviews.author: Manjusha Radhakrishnan

reviews.text: Villeneuve has gone beyond his influences to create a hefty piece of sci-fi world-building that is lost in the spate of films that need to have delineated heroes and villains.
reviews.author: Howard Waldstein

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve’s sequel captures the bleakness and the tragedy at the heart of Frank Herbert’s novel.
reviews.author: David Klion

reviews.text: Folks, it's like this: if you liked or loved Dune: Part One, you will like or love Dune: Part Two.
reviews.author: Jeremy Jahns

reviews.text: There is an emotional depth to it that's missing in the worldbuilding of the initial installment.
reviews.author: Christy Lemire

reviews.text: Villeneuve’s bold stylistic choices, along with the penetrating score by Hans Zimmer result in a film that intensely washes over the senses as it pummels the viewer with beauty and brutality.
reviews.author: Katherine McLaughlin

reviews.text: Granted, a number of character arcs and subplots are resolved perfunctorily, and a handful of defining moments get zero time to breathe. The rest of it, though? The rest of it is impressively close to perfect.
reviews.author: Hayden Mears

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve magnifies the myth of his creation with a pluperfect staging, both epic and poetic, of Frank Herbert's text. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Luis Martínez

reviews.text: It rivals 2015’s “Mad Max: Fury Road” as a staggering, monumental achievement in genre filmmaking and reminds us what truly talented movie directors can do.
reviews.author: Randy Myers

reviews.text: Yes, it is a gorgeous production but not a masterpiece. I’ll be brave and say it: Walken is a feeble lopsided emperor, Bardem is over-acting in his own movie and Bautista’s emotional decimal is higher than everyone else. Only Butler ignites the movie.
reviews.author: Victoria Alexander

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a momentous, jaw-dropping and masterful achievement in cinema that stakes its claim to be the best film of 2024.
reviews.author: Kelechi Ehenulo

reviews.text: A feast for the eyes...Dune: Part Two's jaw-dropping epicness is enough to satisfy one's appetite for spice, cementing itself as one of the best sci-fi sequels of this century.
reviews.author: Katie Smith-Wong

reviews.text: Sci-Fi fans rejoice, DUNE PART 2 is truly remarkable! Denis Villeneuve achieves perfection in this immersive cinematic experience, which includes Zimmer's masterful score and Fraser's best work yet. This is a genuine sci-fi masterpiece!
reviews.author: Elliott Collins

reviews.text: While the war may be portrayed as a jaw-dropping spectacle, the answers to all those political and moral questions may leave the audience deeply uncomfortable. Herbert would be proud.
reviews.author: Richard Whittaker

reviews.text: The film has the makings of a contemporary classic, with the only downside being that we’ll have to wait another few years to see how tensions unfold.
reviews.author: Razmig Bedirian

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two isn’t just an embarrassment of narrative and retinal riches; it’s the sort of big-canvas franchise storytelling we haven’t see since The Lord of the Rings came to a close back at the shire.
reviews.author: Chris Nashawaty

reviews.text: In a film that could have rested on being a visual masterpiece, Villeneuve stays true to the humanity of his direction.
reviews.author: Rachel Ho

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two surpasses even the highest expectations, establishing itself as an unquestionable technical masterpiece of blockbuster filmmaking.
reviews.author: Manuel São Bento

reviews.text: While not quite as groundbreaking as the debut film, Denis Villeneuve pays faithful respect to the source material by putting a complex story ahead of action-oriented spectacle.
reviews.author: Patrick Cavanaugh

reviews.text: The sequel is slower paced than the first installment with the director taking time for Paul Atreides (Timothée Chalamet) to prove himself the messiah to the Freman, which left little time for Paul’s transition.
reviews.author: Lupe Rodriguez Haas

reviews.text: Villenueve has put forth considerable effort to mitigate potential issues with the novel's 'white savior' material, but in the end, has made a movie that is entirely too rad and 'dudes rock' for those efforts to matter or be particularly effective.
reviews.author: Dominic Griffin

reviews.text: A stunning below the line masterpiece that takes surprising and even dark tones, with brilliant performances by Chalamet and Ferguson, even if the story goes by very fast at the core of the film.
reviews.author: J. Don Birnam

reviews.text: Villeneuve’s second chapter tops it’s fantastic predecessor in every possible way with exquisite set pieces, gorgeous visual design, astounding action, and a stunning cast.
reviews.author: Jenn Adams

reviews.text: Manages to keep the storytelling relatively straight and find a human element within all the dense mythology- plus, it's consistently exciting.
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: The sequel, while impressive, loses the restraint and elegance of the first film, leaning more towards a blockbuster experience. The quiet confidence of Part One has morphed into unshackled bravura in Part Two.
reviews.author: Wenlei Ma

reviews.text: Dune Part Two is Empire Strikes Back level great. You have a lead character put to the test and rising to the occasion in epic fashion. The scale is dynamic, and Butler's portrayal is wildly hypnotic and menacing. This is greatness on every level.
reviews.author: Lee McCoy

reviews.text: Watching Dune 2, was like watching The Dark Knight for the first time. Similar to the eternally praised Batman film, Dune 2 feels so good and fulfilling that it will stand out: no matter what came before or comes after it. #diandrareviews
reviews.author: Diandra Reviews

reviews.text: Villeneuve's epic is an incredibly immersive and narratively rich awe-inspiring sci-fi feast. It's so strong across the board that not even an overlong second act and a rushed resolution can diminish its impact. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Nestor Bentancor

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is an epic continuation and builds the potential of what could be one of the greatest science fiction trilogies of all time.
reviews.author: Leo Brady

reviews.text: With an impeccable cast and even grander ambition on display, Dune: Part Two soars as a feat of storytelling. It’s destined to join the ranks of the great sequels and visually stuns at every turn.
reviews.author: Alan French

reviews.text: Blockbuster and IP filmmaking at its finest. Dune: Part Two rocks a script that doesn’t shy away from character complexities, and does a shockingly solid job of reacquainting viewers with the Dune chessboard while adding more pieces to it.
reviews.author: Perri Nemiroff

reviews.text: Despite the long runtime and sluggish first half, "Dune: Part Two" finds its footing in sweeping landscapes aided by gorgeous cinematography, sound design that's loud as all get out, and a host of standout performances from its A-list cast.
reviews.author: Matthew Creith

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is better and spicier than the first, packed with star power, and still too long. Commentary on religion and fanaticism send mixed messages.
reviews.author: Tania Lamb

reviews.text: Heavy with spectacle and theme as it is, Part Two is often surprisingly nimble. As a filmmaker, Villeneuve has long had trouble balancing plot with picture, but here he almost gets the calibration exactly right.
reviews.author: Richard Lawson

reviews.text: “Dune: Part Two” not only does justice to Herbert’s groundbreaking novel, it eclipses 2021’s “Dune” both in scale and ambition.
reviews.author: Kevin Slane

reviews.text: Villeneuve’s great talent lies, I think, in invocation. He may be less perfect when it comes to conclusions but he’s brilliant at summoning -- a sense of doom, a suddenly appeared spacecraft, a sandworm.
reviews.author: Jake Coyle

reviews.text: Emotion and hero's journey complexity course through Denis Villeneuve’s Dune: Part Two like spice, ensuring viewers stay alert and riveted by the sweeping story in addition to basking in astonishing audio/visual spectacle
reviews.author: Robert Kojder

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a truly stunning visual spectacle with a hero’s journey at its heart and is a film that you want to see on the biggest screen possible.
reviews.author: Rachel Leishman

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a masterful technical achievement that surpasses its predecessor movie on a storytelling level. It’s less cluttered with characters than 2021’s Dune and has a more compelling villain and higher emotional stakes.
reviews.author: Carla Hay

reviews.text: A triumphant middle chapter that grapples with inner darkness, ruminative notions of prophecy and destiny, romantic entanglement, and familial tragedy in what is set to be one of the great trilogies and a true modern masterwork.
reviews.author: Matt Oakes

reviews.text: If you're casting a hero whose Chosen One origin is 'I'm The Chosen One: I Have A Note From My Mommy.' Timothée Night Shyamalan is the actor you want.
reviews.author: Bob Chipman

reviews.text: Dune Part Two is a thrilling edge of your seat epic with high stakes, breathtaking filmmaking, and lasting visuals that are all enhanced by another Hans Zimmer score that deepens its emotional core.
reviews.author: Paul McGuire Grimes

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve's sci-fi sequel suffers from some of the same issues as its predecessor, but 'Dune Part Two' such a well-made and well-acted mega-movie that it barely matters
reviews.author: Scott Mendelson

reviews.text: A spectacular feat of science-fiction filmmaking, marrying immersive world-building with engrossing storytelling.
reviews.author: Katie Walsh

reviews.text: As blockbuster movies go, Dune: Part Two is a thrilling ride that totally earns its two-and-a-half-hour running time. The filmmakers add much-needed heft to their display of virtuoso filmmaking by adding serious real-life themes.
reviews.author: Murtada Elfadl

reviews.text: Denis Villeneuve's Dune: Part Two shatters already sky-high expectations by immersing the viewer in a deeply layered, complex narrative. The film takes a Game of Thrones approach to the brutality, politics, and spiritual machinations of fiery revenge.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: It's even more epic than the last. Sound design, costume, and cinematography were firing on all cylinders. This movie is the definition of why people go to the movies. A must see.
reviews.author: Wendy Lee Szany

reviews.text: He has created an exceptional film and a franchise that has set a new standard for sci-fi.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: Dune: Part Two is a The Empire Strikes Back or The Return of the King-level event. A science fiction classic in the making that’ll inspire the next generation of science fiction and fantasy films.
reviews.author: Karl Delossantos

reviews.text: It’s difficult not to get wrapped up in the visuals; the way in which the Dune novel’s many signature characters and adventures are realized are simply stunning.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: An absorbing viewing experience and wholly immersive descent into sci-fi storytelling, frequently sold with incredible magnitude.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: ...gets in your nostrils...
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: The only major issue I can even find with Dune: Part Two is that we had to sit through all of Dune: Part One just to get to the movie Denis Villeneuve actually wanted to make.
reviews.author: Jon Negroni

reviews.text: I know that people use this as a meme, but, whatever. This is cinema. This is why big screen cinematic experiences exist.
reviews.author: Dan Murrell

reviews.text: Dune Part Two is almost 3 hours long, and it still left me wanting more. Denis Villeneuve is back with another sweeping epic. It has to be seen on the biggest screen and the loudest speakers, and the Dolby Atmos version I experienced was shaking my seats.
reviews.author: John Nguyen

reviews.text: ‘Dune: Part Two’ turns up the cinematic heat with a darker, more involving chapter. [It's] the epitome of cerebral entertainment.
reviews.author: Preston Barta

reviews.text: Though visually a knock-out, Denis Villeneuve's second installment repeatedly sheds momentum, something no 166-minute epic can afford to lose.
reviews.author: Dylan Roth
